page.title: 19Geography of N.W.Guildford
page.content: In the south downland,{chalk}forms part of a long north/south ridge known as the Hog's Back. Guildford Cathedral stands on a site known as Stag Hill. The cathedral is the dominant landmark and can be seen from almost every part of the district. In the south east corner the{River {Wey,}one of only 2 rivers to break through the chalk of the North Downs, forms a narrow but important gap through the chalk ridge. This gap was the main reason for the early development of Guildford and the river still dominates the landscape. Most of the area is{London Clay with sandy outcrops which are not very fertile and the land is mainly heath. This part is flat. There is dairy farming in the north west of the region. The sandstone of the {Bagshot Beds}are present here.
